bibl.note: This document is a letter dated October 22, 1803 from Thomas Claiborne, Chairman of the state House of Representatives to the governor of Tennessee, John Sevier. The purpose of the letter is to propose cooperation between the house and executive office, as well as to promise diligent awareness of constituent concerns. Also in the letter, Claiborne makes a point to note the importance of a careful investigation into the American code of laws for any trace of British common law.

div1.p: The general assembly have received, duly weighed, and have well appreciated your very interesting communication of the 7th instant.

The general assembly, feel in all its force, the weighty obligations imposed upon them by the calls of their constituents, whose interests will ever be near to them, and they will use every effort to adopt the salutary means, by which those interests are to be cherished__

The statutes of Great Britain it is true, were enacted in an age of Tyranny & usurpation, yet having been on in a great measure ingrafted into the american code of laws, will require the most accurate investigation to separate them from our civil code__ Happily our wise constitution has guarded against their influence in religious concerns, equally happy for america is it, that the constitutions of the several states are founded on republican principles, and that grand Bulwark of all, the constitution of the United States has guaranteed those invaluable blessings to them. The Legislature is proud to say, that the shackles of british common law, is as little felt here, as in any state of on the union, and this legislature pledge themselves that the Sons of Tennessee, will be foremost in breaking all such improper barriers to freedom__

The Legislature feel with you Sir, the necessity of providing for that valuable & worthy class of citizens resident worth of Tennessee, whose services in the cause of their country, are too deeply impressed, on the minds of every one acquainted acquainted with the settlement of this country to be early forgotten. Their case shall be promptly & early laid before the general government, by the deligation from this state. The
The finances of the state on under investigation, and will meet with due attention.__

It is with extreme regret pain, that the Legislature have to notice the most atrocious murder of Runion__ Every aid in the power of the general assembly, will be cheerfully ordered__ in cooperation with the Executive to bring the perpetrator to condign punishment. The importance of communication between this state and its sister states, is of a too permenent nature to be overlooked, the mortryid attention to this point will meet legislative observation__
The general assembly will with pleasure cooperate with you, in every measure that will tend tend to promote the honor, dignity & prosperity of the state of Tennessee__
